channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: World Briefing: France: Greenpeace Activists Arrested in Break-In
item.description: The police arrested 57 activists who used a truck on Tuesday to break through two security barriers and ram their way into a nuclear power plant in eastern France, the organization said.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing: Guatemala: Ex-President Admits Taking Taiwan Bribes
item.description: Former President Alfonso Portillo pleaded guilty Tuesday in Federal District Court in Manhattan to a charge that he accepted bribes in exchange for diplomatic recognition of Taiwan.
item.dc:creator: By PAULINA VILLEGAS

item.title: Leaked File Details U.S. Phone Monitoring Abroad
item.description: The National Security Agency is recording all phone calls and their routing data in one foreign country and retaining that data for a month so that it can be analyzed, according to a report based on a document leaked by Edward J. Snowden.
item.category: Wiretapping and Other Eavesdropping Devices and Methods
item.dc:creator: By JAMES GLANZ

item.title: News Analysis: If Not a New Cold War, a Distinct Chill in the Air
item.description: Tensions over Crimea may not bring a new Cold War, but analysts worry about a long period of confrontation and alienation.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER
item.media:credit: Uriel Sinai for The New York Times
item.media:description: A soldier stood guard outside a military base on Tuesday in Simferopol, Crimea. Analysts see the threat of a new, riskier era.

item.title: Lisbon Journal: Student Deaths Spark Debate Over Hazing at Portugal’s Universities
item.description: Some credit the ritual with building esprit de corps among students, while others say it has grown increasingly dangerous.
item.dc:creator: By RAPHAEL MINDER
item.media:credit: Francisco Seco for The New York Times
item.media:description: Lusófona University students who support hazing attended an event in February for the six students who drowned in December.

item.title: Defying West, Putin Formally Claims Crimea for Russia
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia said he was reversing what he described as a historical mistake, declaring, “Crimea has always been an integral part of Russia in the hearts and minds of people.”
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN LEE MYERS and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: Demonstrators in Moscow's Red Square carried banners with Mr. Putin's portrait and the slogan "We are together," indicating the reunion of Russia and Crimea.

item.title: News Analysis: Russia’s Aggression in Crimea Brings NATO Into Renewed Focus
item.description: Russia’s moves in Ukraine have revived the North Atlantic Treaty Organization’s role as a counterweight to Moscow, even as it wrestles with its response.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. met Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland, a NATO member state, in Warsaw on Tuesday.

item.title: A Divide Among Palestinians on a Two-State Solution
item.description: A son of President Mahmoud Abbas of the Palestinian Authority is among those younger people expressing support for the creation of a single state.
item.dc:creator: By JODI RUDOREN
item.media:credit: Rina Castelnuovo for The New York Times
item.media:description: “If you don’t want to give me independence, at least give me civil rights,” says Tareq Abbas, 48, a son of the Palestinian Authority president.

item.title: Russia’s Most-Wanted Rebel Is Dead, Website Says
item.description: The site, which represents militant groups in southern Russia, did not say how or when Doku Umarov, a Chechen rebel leader, had died.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: Doku Umarov, who released a video clip last summer in which he threatened to attack the Sochi Olympics.

item.title: U.S. Orders Syrian Embassy and Consulates to Suspend Operations
item.description: The move stops short of a formal break of relations, but it bars Syria’s envoys here from carrying out diplomatic and consular duties.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL R. GORDON

item.title: World Briefing: Egyptian Police Officer Gets 10 Years for Detainees’ Deaths
item.description: A Cairo court sentenced Lt. Col. Amr Farouk in the deaths of 37 people who were arrested for protesting against the military takeover.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK

item.title: Both Sides in Syria Are Targeting Civilians, U.N. Report Says
item.description: Investigators told the Human Rights Council that atrocities toward civilians were increasing as the conflict entered its fourth year.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Islamic State of Iraq and Syria
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: A man with a child found in the rubble of a building on Tuesday in Aleppo, Syria.

item.title: Radar on Mainland Too Robust to Miss a Jet, Experts Say
item.description: If Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 flew north over the Asian mainland, it would have had a hard time avoiding detection by Chinese, Indian or American radar, current and ex-military officers say.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: The Lede: Video of Putin’s Complete Speech on Crimea
item.description: President Vladimir Putin’s address welcoming Crimea to the Russian Federation, and a subsequent signing ceremony, were broadcast with simultaneous English translation by RT, the Kremlin-funded network.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Afghan Leader Picks Ex-Resistance Figure as Deputy
item.description: In nominating a Tajik former interior minister as vice president, President Hamid Karzai preserved the political and ethnic balance at the top of Afghanistan’s government.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW ROSENBERG
item.media:credit: Scott Eells for The New York Times
item.media:description: Yunus Qanooni, a former interior minister, during an interview in 2005.

item.title: West Sees Unity on Iran Despite Crisis in Ukraine
item.description: Iran called for world powers to fulfill promises as negotiators met in Vienna, under the shadow of international tensions over Ukraine and Crimea.
item.dc:creator: By ALISSA J. RUBIN and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Greece Reaches Deal to Release Foreign Rescue Funds
item.description: Negotiations with foreign lenders had dragged on because of disagreements over the extent of austerity Greece must impose and what relief measures it could offer citizens.
item.dc:creator: By NIKI KITSANTONIS

item.title: In Poland, Biden Promises Allies Protection
item.description: In meetings with the leaders of Poland, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. aims to shore up the NATO alliance.
item.dc:creator: By MARK LANDLER
item.media:description: Vice President Joseph R. Biden Jr. met with Prime Minister Donald Tusk of Poland on Tuesday in Warsaw.

item.title: Obama’s Test: Can Penalties Change Russia’s Course?
item.description: As Russian officials essentially laughed off the initial sanctions over Crimea, it was unclear how much more pain the United States could inflict in the long run.
item.dc:creator: By PETER BAKER

item.title: Lost Jet’s Path Seen as Altered via Computer
item.description: The first turn that diverted the missing Malaysia Airlines plane from its route was entered into a computer system, most likely by someone in the plane’s cockpit, American officials said.
item.dc:creator: By MATTHEW L. WALD and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: A Malaysia Airlines Boeing 777-200ER, flight 318 to Beijing, sat on the tarmac Monday at Kuala Lumpur International Airport. Flight 318 replaces 370, retired out of respect to the passengers and crew of the missing plane.

item.title: Major Balkan Drug Trafficker Arrested in Serbia, Authorities Say
item.description: Darko Saric, described as running a drug ring that stretched from Latin American to Europe, agreed to turn himself in, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Blast in Golan Heights Wounds 4 Israeli Soldiers
item.description: An explosive device struck near an Israeli Army patrol, in an attack seen as the most serious in recent weeks on Israel’s northern borders.
item.dc:creator: By ISABEL KERSHNER
item.media:description: Israeli soldiers prepared to evacuate a comrade wounded by a roadside bomb on Tuesday in the Golan Heights.

item.title: Confirmation of Shake-Up in China’s Film Industry
item.description: Han Sanping is stepping down as chairman of the China Film Group, a government-sponsored company that supervises film imports to China.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL CIEPLY

item.title: If History Is a Guide, Crimeans’ Celebration May Be Short-Lived
item.description: South Ossetia had high hopes when Russia took control of the enclave from Georgia in 2008, but its economy is stagnant and corruption is rife.
item.dc:creator: By OLESYA VARTANYAN and ELLEN BARRY
item.media:credit: Justyna Mielnikiewicz for The New York Times
item.media:description: Youths waited for a bus in Atotsi, Georgia, near the border with South Ossetia, where men in unmarked military uniforms recently started building a border fence.

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: March 18
item.description: A member of a nongovernmental organization creating awareness among people about votes for sale in the upcoming general elections due in April-May.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A member of a nongovernmental organization in Bangalore, Karnataka, displaying a badge to create awareness among people for the upcoming general elections due in April-May.
